metadata.synopsis: Lame in one leg, Ryan Jeffers (Mario Yedidia) has few friends in his high school and spends most of his time with Chinese restaurant chef Ming (Dennis Dun), who gives him the Book of Tao. When he is goaded by the football team into a dangerous ceremony, Ryan falls into a whirlpool and emerges in the magical land of Tao. His leg fully healed, he is led to Master Chung (Chao-Li-Chi), whose heroic warriors battle against greedy Lord Komodo (Angus Macfadyen). Ryan joins their fight.

reviews: Only one element remains clearly traceable to Hong Kong cinema: The titular warriors are badly dubbed.
Enchantingly peculiar, and Angus MacFadyen is hilarious.
Warriors of Virtue could be the most impressive Hollywood debut yet for a Hong Kong director, although lackluster writing and a needlessly muddled storyline somewhat tarnish the effort.
It sounds ridiculous and, rest assured, it is.
Warriors of Virtue is a great title. Unfortunately, it's not a great movie.
The movie looks better than it plays and gets rather tiresome.
